In my opinion, the Catholic Church needs to adapt in several ways. They have been grappling with a decline in followers, and I believe this is due to their lack of acceptance on numerous issues. For instance, their stance on gay marriages, abortion, and birth control can be quite rigid. I think if they were to evolve their thinking a bit, they might not face such a loss in their following.

I've heard that many are starting to distance themselves from the Catholic Church due to their views on these topics. People are no longer aligned with their stances on these issues, which is causing them to feel uncomfortable within the church. For example, if you support abortion, you might not feel comfortable in a community where it's seen as completely wrong. Similarly, if you're for gay marriage, you might struggle in a following that doesn't agree with it.

I don't understand why the Catholic Church can't have female priests or allow priests to be married. The church claims that priests are married to God, yet everyone else in the world has both a job and a family life. I'm not sure why priests can't have both as well.

In my opinion, I’m not against gay marriage. I honestly don’t see it as a conscious choice that gay people make. It just seems like they are born that way, and we shouldn’t hold them responsible for their sexual orientation. I don’t think it’s right to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can’t. I haven’t given it much thought, but I would definitely say that’s wrong. It’s not like they have a say in how they are born. I was born straight, and someone else is born gay, it doesn’t seem fair to hold them accountable. I don’t think the federal government should be involved in this. It’s not a legal or moral issue, and I don’t think they have a right to interfere in people’s lives. It’s just who they are, and they shouldn’t be punished for that. That’s all.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized, and here’s why. There's really no solid reason to oppose it. Some people argue that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional families, but it's actually quite different. It’s like comparing two sides of the same coin. Heads will never be tails, yet it's essentially the same thing. Let’s talk about the practical aspects. Many civil rights are tied to marriage, such as property taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't be with you in a hospital or visit you because they're not technically family. That seems silly if you're spending your life with someone. Plus, scientific studies show that homosexual couples have the same relationship success rates and satisfaction rates as heterosexual couples.

The main issue is that homosexuals aren't asking for the right to marry in a church, they just want a legal document provided by the government. If there’s no religious involvement, it shouldn't be an issue. Some people, like Catholics, argue that it’s against their religion and morally wrong, but in a legal sense, if you're allowing civil unions, why not marriage? It’s like segregation: separate but unequal. Gay couples are the same in many ways, like relationship roles played by partners. People worry about adoption and community issues, but again, the main concern is how children are treated. In New York City, for instance, children of gay parents have special schools because they face bullying in public schools. But parenting skills don't differ between gay and straight couples. The federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state, and the amendment should be changed to reflect that.

President Bush has strong views on this issue, largely based on his religion, similar to his stance on abortion and stem cell research. Most of his reasons are moral, which vary from person to person. It’s unethical to embrace one group's morality while ignoring others. It’s hypocritical for the government to enforce religious standards on an entire country, considering the recent controversy over "under God” in the pledge of allegiance.

Many people are anti-gay and anti-gay marriage because they believe that gay people are psychologically damaged. But the American Psychological Association says this is untrue. If we listened to institutions that do research and studies, society might see things differently.

Let me start by sharing my experience working as a pharmacy intern over the summer. Now, it's important to note that just because a substance is illegal doesn't mean it lacks medicinal benefits. I strongly believe that while we should not make it widely available to the public just yet, utilizing it for medicinal purposes is a different story. For instance, there are controlled substances like oxycodone and Vicodin that are often used in a clinical setting because they provide genuine benefits. Denying these benefits just because of marijuana's taboo status is not productive in my opinion.

I must also emphasize that while marijuana and alcohol are both subject to abuse, marijuana is generally considered less harmful. Integrating marijuana into society gradually, rather than all at once, could be a viable solution. First, we should remove the stigma associated with marijuana to encourage responsible use. If we can achieve this, people might be better equipped to use marijuana responsibly for both recreational and medicinal purposes.

In conclusion, I contend that the benefits of marijuana should not be dismissed solely based on its illegal status. By embracing its medicinal properties and addressing the taboo surrounding it, we can pave the way for a more responsible and regulated future for marijuana.

I believe the church has made adjustments to adapt to the twenty-first century. It isn't as rigid as it used to be. When I was younger, I would always attend church every Sunday, dressed in cute little dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. I went to a private school, so I'd see all my friends there on weekends, but now, as I've aged, they've introduced a teen mass that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially during summer when you'll see folks in beach clothes, and families often arrive late. Even at morning masses, where I used to dress up, people now wear jeans and khakis. The church I know has also seen a shift in its political landscape, but I'm not privy to the intricacies. Overall, I think it has become more casual.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests and child abuse, I don't think these issues could have been prevented by allowing female priests or permitting priests to marry. Married men can still become pedophiles due to their genetics, and it's not always a lifestyle choice. Many religions allow their clergy to marry, but if a priest truly wants to practice their faith and be married, they might consider a different faith. I believe pedophilia is primarily genetic rather than environmental, and marriage wouldn't change that. If the church knew about the abuse and covered it up, it's shameful, but I believe in many cases, they may not have been aware. I have no other significant thoughts on the Catholic church.

Initially, I was fine with the initial premise, but as we were still recovering from the September 11th attacks, everyone was quite shaken. The Bush administration used various pretexts to justify going into Iraq, claiming connections to Osama Bin Laden and linking the war to the attacks. They also alleged that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which we now know were never proven true. This really grates on me, and the Iraq war has always made my blood boil.

I believe the Bush administration straightforwardly lied to the American people and has not taken responsibility for it. Even Colin Powell, who gave a major presentation at the UN, later admitted that he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time. To me, this is malfeasance in office and an impeachable offense. They have shown complete disregard for the Constitution and have been trying to undermine it ever since, especially since September 11th. I think they entered office with the intent to go to war.

I can’t recall the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who made this allegation in his book after being forced out, but it seems like the younger Bush was driven by a sense of blood vengeance against Saddam Hussein due to his father's administration. He also had long-term plans to expand our energy supply, which was quite underhanded. However, I believe the situation has dragged on long enough.

If we withdraw now, there’s a high risk of civil war and even more deaths. The alternative being considered by the UN and the US is a coalition of surrounding nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia to restore order. However, I'm not sure this is a good idea in the long term because it will bring up issues of Iraq’s sovereignty. The interim government seems to be falling apart, as the news reports suggest the Parliament isn’t very effective. The Prime Minister seems to lack control over the political process, and even Muqtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting against less than a year ago, now holds a significant number of seats in the Iraqi Parliament. The political process is quite tumultuous due to these radical elements vying for control.

None of this can be articulated in polite company.

I guess I don't really know how I feel about the War in Iraq. I mean, it's like, what's the point? It wasn't even declared a war. It's more like a big get-back-at-Iraq thing, right? I mean, who do we think did 9/11? So, I don't really follow the details of it, but I know we're kind of just over there trying to build democracy and get oil. But it's not making anyone happy, and if we stay, we'll have to try to create democracy, which takes forever. And if we leave, they'll be mad at us for messing everything up again. It's so confusing! I mean, it's like, why are we still there? I don't know! I'm not really for the war, but I don't know if I'm against it either. It's hard to say. I don't think we should call it a war anymore because it doesn't feel like one. We just have all these big guns and stuff to show we're powerful. But I don't think it's fair. It's like the Vietnam War, it was never declared, and now it's called a meaningless war. And I don't want Bush to be remembered as the worst president ever. It's just so unfair. And there are so many families with kids in Iraq, and I don't want to see them hurt. But if we stay, we'll be trying to mold them into something they're not. And that could make things worse. I mean, who knows what's going to happen in the end? It's just so hard to say. I guess it's going to go on for years.

I strongly feel it's not appropriate for a state to legalize it or for the government to even consider it. I believe it's a matter that should be left to the churches, as the constitution explicitly states the separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any regulations over it would be a breach of what's already established in the constitution. I find it hypocritical for those who are pushing for its illegality to impose their beliefs on others, particularly when most Catholics and Christians oppose it. The separation of church and state is a fundamental principle of our constitution, promoting religious tolerance. I don't see why making an amendment about this issue would be necessary or beneficial, as it would only restrict people rather than the government. I don't think the federal government should be involved in this at all. The president's push for this amendment is clearly driven by his personal beliefs as a Catholic, and it's not justified by any logical or economic reasons. In fact, it could potentially have a positive impact on society. I've said my piece on this topic.

Ok, let's talk about the war in Iraq.

Well, to get started, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for the war. Before invading Iraq, I believe there was an attempt to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality, they had very little to do with each other. The government used the emotions of the American people, who were outraged by the terrorist attacks, to justify the invasion, which started in 2003.

Now, I'm generally against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think the government should have learned from the Vietnam War. The Iraq War was, in many ways, similar to Vietnam. The U.S. removed the Iraqi government and tried to implement a democratic government, just like they did in Vietnam. But they were not prepared for the chaos and power vacuum that followed, and more importantly, they were not prepared for the insurgents who fought against them.

I think the government should have planned for all possible outcomes. The war in Iraq has been going on for years, and many American troops have died. The U.S. is still there today, trying to train Iraqi troops and police forces to police their own country. It's a long process, and I don't think the government was prepared for it.

The U.S. government also made it seem like the invasion would be a short, successful mission, which was naïve. It's not an easy thing to implement a new form of government, especially after a long war. It took our own country a long time to become the powerful democracy it is today, with a lot of tension and civil war along the way.

In the 2004 presidential election, I would have voted for George Bush to let him finish what he started, because it's hard to abandon the people we've been helping. But at the same time, we need to consider the staggering number of American casualties and how much is too much to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq.

If we're invading Iraq to make it a democratic nation, why aren't we doing the same for other countries? I think the main reason is oil. The U.S. is getting its oil from Iraq, and it's usually all about money and controlling resources. Before the invasion, there were claims that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but none were ever found. Yet, places like North Korea, which we know have these weapons, are not being attacked. I don't think the U.S. government is being thorough or truthful enough in their decisions.

I just hope it ends soon, and there's peace there soon, but probably not.

I am in favor of gay marriage, I've always been. It's a personal preference, and it's been proven to have biological roots rather than sociological ones. This means that denying people the right to marry someone they love based on something they can't control is inhumane. I've always advocated for gay marriage and I believe that politics and government should stay out of people's personal lives. In my neighborhood, there are a few openly gay couples who don't have the same rights as straight couples, but they function just like any other family. I think it's ridiculous for politicians to try and interpret marriage in a way that suits them. It's a personal matter, not a national or federal concern. I've heard from many sources that being homosexual can be influenced by biology, not upbringing. For example, a chemical reaction in the brain might predispose someone to be homosexual, rather than societal factors. It's unfair that two people can get married in secret without anyone knowing, but two gay people wanting to do the same gets front-page news. I believe marriage should be a private matter, not a public one.

I feel like the war has dragged on far too long. Initially, the purpose seemed noble: to restore democracy in a country lacking a fair political system. However, I believe we've lost sight of that goal, and now it appears we're simply continuing the conflict to assert our status as a global superpower. Perhaps there were personal interests at play, like the previous feud between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein. While spreading democracy was a valid motivation, any hint of personal gain would have been unfair. I believe our initial goal was achieved in the first few months, as the war's start itself was a significant statement. Still, the prolonged conflict has left the original purpose diluted and misconceived, as it seems we're still at war for the sake of being at war, aiming for a decisive end that may never come.

In my opinion, the war has dragged on far too long. If our main objective was to install democracy in a country ruled by a tyrant, that would have been a just cause. However, I don't think our reasons have stayed true to this original intent. It seems we're still waging war just to wage war, without a clear end goal in sight. It's high time we let the local government take the reins and step back, as they will eventually have to handle their own affairs anyway. We've been pouring billions of dollars into this conflict, which could be better spent addressing our own pressing issues like poverty and infrastructure. It's a drain on our economy to keep funding a war that has lost its purpose over time.

I wanted to clarify something. It seems that the situation you're referring to was prevented because someone went online and found some information. Anyway, I think it's okay. On platforms like Myspace, if you post information, it's pretty much accessible to everyone. You have to understand that when you give someone access to your profile, you're allowing them to see it. So, if someone spotted something and prevented a situation, that's not an invasion of privacy. However, it might be difficult to monitor every profile to ensure safety, but it becomes discriminatory if they only target the "bad kids." It depends on the context—whether they were actively searching for something specific or just stumbled upon it. I don't know, it's a tricky issue. I use Facebook, and I'm always aware that there are creepy people out there. I saw a TV show where a man easily found someone's information and convinced her to meet him. It's scary. Sometimes, people I don't recognize on my class list IM me, and I wonder if they know too much about me. It's a dangerous game balancing privacy and communication. I only accept people I know, but you never know who can see what. My roommate mentioned that her high school banned students from having Myspace, which seems a bit strange. I'm not sure if that's a privacy issue or if they had the right to do that. It's a complex situation.

I understand that they didn’t outright legalize it, but rather decriminalized it. This means that getting caught with it is treated more like getting a traffic ticket than a criminal offense. While a decriminalized charge can still have serious future ramifications, such as making it difficult to pass a job interview, it does reduce the immediate consequences of being arrested and booked. On the other hand, there are costs involved in arresting, housing, and bringing individuals to court, especially in financially struggling communities. In a place like Denver, where the community tends to be more open-minded and liberal, decriminalizing marijuana might be a good decision. This could potentially free up funds for public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. However, it's important to consider that widespread legalization could lead to marijuana being sold in gas stations and smoked in public, which might not be desirable. Additionally, while alcohol may have more immediate effects on motor skills, marijuana often has a more enduring impact on an individual's lifestyle. I don't think that either substance should be generalized, as people react differently based on their personalities and behaviors.

In my opinion, yes, there are some things that the Catholic Church has done traditionally that are quite old-fashioned. They've maintained these customs for long periods, which is good for grounding and maintaining traditions. However, it's also crucial to be open-minded to change. Many Catholics feel that they must attend Church weekly and adhere strictly to the Church's rules. This strictness sometimes makes it seem like the Church doesn't accept those who don't follow the doctrine perfectly or aren't Catholic. For instance, my parents faced difficulties when it came to getting married in the Church because my father was an Episcopalian. This isn't really tolerant of other religions, which goes against the Church's teachings on loving others. I believe many Catholic doctrines tell us what to do, but the Church's practices don't always align with these teachings due to their outdated nature. I think it's a good idea to allow priests to marry, but I don't believe it would necessarily prevent pedophilic behavior. I think priests would act that way whether they're married or not, as the act involves children, not spouses. Therefore, I don't think allowing priests to marry would deter them from these behaviors. In my view, it wouldn't make a difference.

I'm still undecided on this issue, so I can't declare one side as right or wrong. However, I believe this is one of the most complex topics we're dealing with today. The debate lies between the separation of church and state and how to define marriage, which is tricky without offending anyone. I think civil unions, regardless of the ceremony's religious context, should be treated equally by the government. After all, they're unions between two people, and the government shouldn't concern itself with the type of ceremony or religious significance. But if states can come to a logical consensus, they should push for federal recognition of civil unions. A constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is absurd; it's not a cause large enough to warrant amending the constitution. It's simply not that important to amend the constitution to define or ban gay marriage.

You know, I was brought up in a Christian household, so my views on homosexuality are a bit nuanced. I've got a lot of gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather a decision left to each state. I mean, there are so many democratic and republican states, and you can't deny that democratic states will likely push for gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you're choosing to live there, so you should accept that state's position on the issue. I believe homosexuals deserve the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I think the decision should be up to each state.

I also think Bush shouldn't have a say in whether or not the whole country should be against gay marriage. I mean, he doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't dictate how each state wants to run. Plus, he'll be out of office soon enough, so it doesn't matter what he decides. I think some things are better left up to the individual states, as they'll be the ones to live with the decision. Let's just leave it at that.

So, no, I don't think they should do that at all. Let me explain why. Myspace, it's a public platform, right? If you look at the definition, it's basically for people to see whatever you post. Now, if you post something on the internet, you have to realize that people will see it. It could be school officials or anyone else. They might see something you didn't intend for them to see. But, if something on the internet could potentially prevent a school shooting, then I think that's perfectly fine. It's the school officials' responsibility to ensure the safety of students, and this might help them do just that. Now, if they're just using the internet to catch students in trouble, that's an invasion of privacy. But if they're doing it for the greater good, to make the school safer, then I don't think it's an invasion at all. I mean, if you're a student posting something on Myspace and you don't expect to get in trouble, that's crazy. Everything you post on the internet is for the world to see, and it can come back to bite you later. If you don't want something to be seen, don't post it. And if they have something that leads them to make the school a safer place, then it's fine. But if they're just doing it to catch students, that's not good. It's like they're dropping their kids off at school and expecting it to be a safe place, and the school officials are doing their duty to ensure that. That's why they do drills and practice for emergencies. They're just trying to make the school safer and prevent anything bad from happening, like what happened at Columbine. That's all I have to say.

In my opinion, the Catholic Church needs to adapt in several ways. They have been grappling with a decline in followers, and I believe this is due to their lack of acceptance on numerous issues. For instance, their stance on gay marriages, abortion, and birth control can be quite rigid. I think if they were to evolve their thinking a bit, they might not face such a loss in their following.

I've heard that many are starting to distance themselves from the Catholic Church due to their views on these topics. People are no longer aligned with their stances on these issues, which is causing them to feel uncomfortable within the church. For example, if you support abortion, you might not feel comfortable in a community where it's seen as completely wrong. Similarly, if you're for gay marriage, you might struggle in a following that doesn't agree with it.

I don't understand why the Catholic Church can't have female priests or allow priests to be married. The church claims that priests are married to God, yet everyone else in the world has both a job and a family life. I'm not sure why priests can't have both as well.

In my opinion, I’m not against gay marriage. I honestly don’t see it as a conscious choice that gay people make. It just seems like they are born that way, and we shouldn’t hold them responsible for their sexual orientation. I don’t think it’s right to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can’t. I haven’t given it much thought, but I would definitely say that’s wrong. It’s not like they have a say in how they are born. I was born straight, and someone else is born gay, it doesn’t seem fair to hold them accountable. I don’t think the federal government should be involved in this. It’s not a legal or moral issue, and I don’t think they have a right to interfere in people’s lives. It’s just who they are, and they shouldn’t be punished for that. That’s all.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized, and here’s why. There's really no solid reason to oppose it. Some people argue that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional families, but it's actually quite different. It’s like comparing two sides of the same coin. Heads will never be tails, yet it's essentially the same thing. Let’s talk about the practical aspects. Many civil rights are tied to marriage, such as property taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't be with you in a hospital or visit you because they're not technically family. That seems silly if you're spending your life with someone. Plus, scientific studies show that homosexual couples have the same relationship success rates and satisfaction rates as heterosexual couples.

The main issue is that homosexuals aren't asking for the right to marry in a church, they just want a legal document provided by the government. If there’s no religious involvement, it shouldn't be an issue. Some people, like Catholics, argue that it’s against their religion and morally wrong, but in a legal sense, if you're allowing civil unions, why not marriage? It’s like segregation: separate but unequal. Gay couples are the same in many ways, like relationship roles played by partners. People worry about adoption and community issues, but again, the main concern is how children are treated. In New York City, for instance, children of gay parents have special schools because they face bullying in public schools. But parenting skills don't differ between gay and straight couples. The federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state, and the amendment should be changed to reflect that.

President Bush has strong views on this issue, largely based on his religion, similar to his stance on abortion and stem cell research. Most of his reasons are moral, which vary from person to person. It’s unethical to embrace one group's morality while ignoring others. It’s hypocritical for the government to enforce religious standards on an entire country, considering the recent controversy over "under God” in the pledge of allegiance.

Many people are anti-gay and anti-gay marriage because they believe that gay people are psychologically damaged. But the American Psychological Association says this is untrue. If we listened to institutions that do research and studies, society might see things differently.

Let me start by sharing my experience working as a pharmacy intern over the summer. Now, it's important to note that just because a substance is illegal doesn't mean it lacks medicinal benefits. I strongly believe that while we should not make it widely available to the public just yet, utilizing it for medicinal purposes is a different story. For instance, there are controlled substances like oxycodone and Vicodin that are often used in a clinical setting because they provide genuine benefits. Denying these benefits just because of marijuana's taboo status is not productive in my opinion.

I must also emphasize that while marijuana and alcohol are both subject to abuse, marijuana is generally considered less harmful. Integrating marijuana into society gradually, rather than all at once, could be a viable solution. First, we should remove the stigma associated with marijuana to encourage responsible use. If we can achieve this, people might be better equipped to use marijuana responsibly for both recreational and medicinal purposes.

In conclusion, I contend that the benefits of marijuana should not be dismissed solely based on its illegal status. By embracing its medicinal properties and addressing the taboo surrounding it, we can pave the way for a more responsible and regulated future for marijuana.

I believe the church has made adjustments to adapt to the twenty-first century. It isn't as rigid as it used to be. When I was younger, I would always attend church every Sunday, dressed in cute little dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. I went to a private school, so I'd see all my friends there on weekends, but now, as I've aged, they've introduced a teen mass that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially during summer when you'll see folks in beach clothes, and families often arrive late. Even at morning masses, where I used to dress up, people now wear jeans and khakis. The church I know has also seen a shift in its political landscape, but I'm not privy to the intricacies. Overall, I think it has become more casual.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests and child abuse, I don't think these issues could have been prevented by allowing female priests or permitting priests to marry. Married men can still become pedophiles due to their genetics, and it's not always a lifestyle choice. Many religions allow their clergy to marry, but if a priest truly wants to practice their faith and be married, they might consider a different faith. I believe pedophilia is primarily genetic rather than environmental, and marriage wouldn't change that. If the church knew about the abuse and covered it up, it's shameful, but I believe in many cases, they may not have been aware. I have no other significant thoughts on the Catholic church.

Initially, I was fine with the initial premise, but as we were still recovering from the September 11th attacks, everyone was quite shaken. The Bush administration used various pretexts to justify going into Iraq, claiming connections to Osama Bin Laden and linking the war to the attacks. They also alleged that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which we now know were never proven true. This really grates on me, and the Iraq war has always made my blood boil.

I believe the Bush administration straightforwardly lied to the American people and has not taken responsibility for it. Even Colin Powell, who gave a major presentation at the UN, later admitted that he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time. To me, this is malfeasance in office and an impeachable offense. They have shown complete disregard for the Constitution and have been trying to undermine it ever since, especially since September 11th. I think they entered office with the intent to go to war.

I can’t recall the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who made this allegation in his book after being forced out, but it seems like the younger Bush was driven by a sense of blood vengeance against Saddam Hussein due to his father's administration. He also had long-term plans to expand our energy supply, which was quite underhanded. However, I believe the situation has dragged on long enough.

If we withdraw now, there’s a high risk of civil war and even more deaths. The alternative being considered by the UN and the US is a coalition of surrounding nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia to restore order. However, I'm not sure this is a good idea in the long term because it will bring up issues of Iraq’s sovereignty. The interim government seems to be falling apart, as the news reports suggest the Parliament isn’t very effective. The Prime Minister seems to lack control over the political process, and even Muqtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting against less than a year ago, now holds a significant number of seats in the Iraqi Parliament. The political process is quite tumultuous due to these radical elements vying for control.

None of this can be articulated in polite company.

I guess I don't really know how I feel about the War in Iraq. I mean, it's like, what's the point? It wasn't even declared a war. It's more like a big get-back-at-Iraq thing, right? I mean, who do we think did 9/11? So, I don't really follow the details of it, but I know we're kind of just over there trying to build democracy and get oil. But it's not making anyone happy, and if we stay, we'll have to try to create democracy, which takes forever. And if we leave, they'll be mad at us for messing everything up again. It's so confusing! I mean, it's like, why are we still there? I don't know! I'm not really for the war, but I don't know if I'm against it either. It's hard to say. I don't think we should call it a war anymore because it doesn't feel like one. We just have all these big guns and stuff to show we're powerful. But I don't think it's fair. It's like the Vietnam War, it was never declared, and now it's called a meaningless war. And I don't want Bush to be remembered as the worst president ever. It's just so unfair. And there are so many families with kids in Iraq, and I don't want to see them hurt. But if we stay, we'll be trying to mold them into something they're not. And that could make things worse. I mean, who knows what's going to happen in the end? It's just so hard to say. I guess it's going to go on for years.

I strongly feel it's not appropriate for a state to legalize it or for the government to even consider it. I believe it's a matter that should be left to the churches, as the constitution explicitly states the separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any regulations over it would be a breach of what's already established in the constitution. I find it hypocritical for those who are pushing for its illegality to impose their beliefs on others, particularly when most Catholics and Christians oppose it. The separation of church and state is a fundamental principle of our constitution, promoting religious tolerance. I don't see why making an amendment about this issue would be necessary or beneficial, as it would only restrict people rather than the government. I don't think the federal government should be involved in this at all. The president's push for this amendment is clearly driven by his personal beliefs as a Catholic, and it's not justified by any logical or economic reasons. In fact, it could potentially have a positive impact on society. I've said my piece on this topic.

Ok, let's talk about the war in Iraq.

Well, to get started, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for the war. Before invading Iraq, I believe there was an attempt to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality, they had very little to do with each other. The government used the emotions of the American people, who were outraged by the terrorist attacks, to justify the invasion, which started in 2003.

Now, I'm generally against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think the government should have learned from the Vietnam War. The Iraq War was, in many ways, similar to Vietnam. The U.S. removed the Iraqi government and tried to implement a democratic government, just like they did in Vietnam. But they were not prepared for the chaos and power vacuum that followed, and more importantly, they were not prepared for the insurgents who fought against them.

I think the government should have planned for all possible outcomes. The war in Iraq has been going on for years, and many American troops have died. The U.S. is still there today, trying to train Iraqi troops and police forces to police their own country. It's a long process, and I don't think the government was prepared for it.

The U.S. government also made it seem like the invasion would be a short, successful mission, which was naïve. It's not an easy thing to implement a new form of government, especially after a long war. It took our own country a long time to become the powerful democracy it is today, with a lot of tension and civil war along the way.

In the 2004 presidential election, I would have voted for George Bush to let him finish what he started, because it's hard to abandon the people we've been helping. But at the same time, we need to consider the staggering number of American casualties and how much is too much to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq.

If we're invading Iraq to make it a democratic nation, why aren't we doing the same for other countries? I think the main reason is oil. The U.S. is getting its oil from Iraq, and it's usually all about money and controlling resources. Before the invasion, there were claims that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but none were ever found. Yet, places like North Korea, which we know have these weapons, are not being attacked. I don't think the U.S. government is being thorough or truthful enough in their decisions.

I just hope it ends soon, and there's peace there soon, but probably not.

I am in favor of gay marriage, I've always been. It's a personal preference, and it's been proven to have biological roots rather than sociological ones. This means that denying people the right to marry someone they love based on something they can't control is inhumane. I've always advocated for gay marriage and I believe that politics and government should stay out of people's personal lives. In my neighborhood, there are a few openly gay couples who don't have the same rights as straight couples, but they function just like any other family. I think it's ridiculous for politicians to try and interpret marriage in a way that suits them. It's a personal matter, not a national or federal concern. I've heard from many sources that being homosexual can be influenced by biology, not upbringing. For example, a chemical reaction in the brain might predispose someone to be homosexual, rather than societal factors. It's unfair that two people can get married in secret without anyone knowing, but two gay people wanting to do the same gets front-page news. I believe marriage should be a private matter, not a public one.

I feel like the war has dragged on far too long. Initially, the purpose seemed noble: to restore democracy in a country lacking a fair political system. However, I believe we've lost sight of that goal, and now it appears we're simply continuing the conflict to assert our status as a global superpower. Perhaps there were personal interests at play, like the previous feud between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein. While spreading democracy was a valid motivation, any hint of personal gain would have been unfair. I believe our initial goal was achieved in the first few months, as the war's start itself was a significant statement. Still, the prolonged conflict has left the original purpose diluted and misconceived, as it seems we're still at war for the sake of being at war, aiming for a decisive end that may never come.

In my opinion, the war has dragged on far too long. If our main objective was to install democracy in a country ruled by a tyrant, that would have been a just cause. However, I don't think our reasons have stayed true to this original intent. It seems we're still waging war just to wage war, without a clear end goal in sight. It's high time we let the local government take the reins and step back, as they will eventually have to handle their own affairs anyway. We've been pouring billions of dollars into this conflict, which could be better spent addressing our own pressing issues like poverty and infrastructure. It's a drain on our economy to keep funding a war that has lost its purpose over time.

I wanted to clarify something. It seems that the situation you're referring to was prevented because someone went online and found some information. Anyway, I think it's okay. On platforms like Myspace, if you post information, it's pretty much accessible to everyone. You have to understand that when you give someone access to your profile, you're allowing them to see it. So, if someone spotted something and prevented a situation, that's not an invasion of privacy. However, it might be difficult to monitor every profile to ensure safety, but it becomes discriminatory if they only target the "bad kids." It depends on the context—whether they were actively searching for something specific or just stumbled upon it. I don't know, it's a tricky issue. I use Facebook, and I'm always aware that there are creepy people out there. I saw a TV show where a man easily found someone's information and convinced her to meet him. It's scary. Sometimes, people I don't recognize on my class list IM me, and I wonder if they know too much about me. It's a dangerous game balancing privacy and communication. I only accept people I know, but you never know who can see what. My roommate mentioned that her high school banned students from having Myspace, which seems a bit strange. I'm not sure if that's a privacy issue or if they had the right to do that. It's a complex situation.

I understand that they didn’t outright legalize it, but rather decriminalized it. This means that getting caught with it is treated more like getting a traffic ticket than a criminal offense. While a decriminalized charge can still have serious future ramifications, such as making it difficult to pass a job interview, it does reduce the immediate consequences of being arrested and booked. On the other hand, there are costs involved in arresting, housing, and bringing individuals to court, especially in financially struggling communities. In a place like Denver, where the community tends to be more open-minded and liberal, decriminalizing marijuana might be a good decision. This could potentially free up funds for public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. However, it's important to consider that widespread legalization could lead to marijuana being sold in gas stations and smoked in public, which might not be desirable. Additionally, while alcohol may have more immediate effects on motor skills, marijuana often has a more enduring impact on an individual's lifestyle. I don't think that either substance should be generalized, as people react differently based on their personalities and behaviors.

In my opinion, yes, there are some things that the Catholic Church has done traditionally that are quite old-fashioned. They've maintained these customs for long periods, which is good for grounding and maintaining traditions. However, it's also crucial to be open-minded to change. Many Catholics feel that they must attend Church weekly and adhere strictly to the Church's rules. This strictness sometimes makes it seem like the Church doesn't accept those who don't follow the doctrine perfectly or aren't Catholic. For instance, my parents faced difficulties when it came to getting married in the Church because my father was an Episcopalian. This isn't really tolerant of other religions, which goes against the Church's teachings on loving others. I believe many Catholic doctrines tell us what to do, but the Church's practices don't always align with these teachings due to their outdated nature. I think it's a good idea to allow priests to marry, but I don't believe it would necessarily prevent pedophilic behavior. I think priests would act that way whether they're married or not, as the act involves children, not spouses. Therefore, I don't think allowing priests to marry would deter them from these behaviors. In my view, it wouldn't make a difference.

I'm still undecided on this issue, so I can't declare one side as right or wrong. However, I believe this is one of the most complex topics we're dealing with today. The debate lies between the separation of church and state and how to define marriage, which is tricky without offending anyone. I think civil unions, regardless of the ceremony's religious context, should be treated equally by the government. After all, they're unions between two people, and the government shouldn't concern itself with the type of ceremony or religious significance. But if states can come to a logical consensus, they should push for federal recognition of civil unions. A constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is absurd; it's not a cause large enough to warrant amending the constitution. It's simply not that important to amend the constitution to define or ban gay marriage.

You know, I was brought up in a Christian household, so my views on homosexuality are a bit nuanced. I've got a lot of gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather a decision left to each state. I mean, there are so many democratic and republican states, and you can't deny that democratic states will likely push for gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you're choosing to live there, so you should accept that state's position on the issue. I believe homosexuals deserve the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I think the decision should be up to each state.

I also think Bush shouldn't have a say in whether or not the whole country should be against gay marriage. I mean, he doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't dictate how each state wants to run. Plus, he'll be out of office soon enough, so it doesn't matter what he decides. I think some things are better left up to the individual states, as they'll be the ones to live with the decision. Let's just leave it at that.

So, no, I don't think they should do that at all. Let me explain why. Myspace, it's a public platform, right? If you look at the definition, it's basically for people to see whatever you post. Now, if you post something on the internet, you have to realize that people will see it. It could be school officials or anyone else. They might see something you didn't intend for them to see. But, if something on the internet could potentially prevent a school shooting, then I think that's perfectly fine. It's the school officials' responsibility to ensure the safety of students, and this might help them do just that. Now, if they're just using the internet to catch students in trouble, that's an invasion of privacy. But if they're doing it for the greater good, to make the school safer, then I don't think it's an invasion at all. I mean, if you're a student posting something on Myspace and you don't expect to get in trouble, that's crazy. Everything you post on the internet is for the world to see, and it can come back to bite you later. If you don't want something to be seen, don't post it. And if they have something that leads them to make the school a safer place, then it's fine. But if they're just doing it to catch students, that's not good. It's like they're dropping their kids off at school and expecting it to be a safe place, and the school officials are doing their duty to ensure that. That's why they do drills and practice for emergencies. They're just trying to make the school safer and prevent anything bad from happening, like what happened at Columbine. That's all I have to say.

In my opinion, the Catholic Church needs to adapt in several ways. They have been grappling with a decline in followers, and I believe this is due to their lack of acceptance on numerous issues. For instance, their stance on gay marriages, abortion, and birth control can be quite rigid. I think if they were to evolve their thinking a bit, they might not face such a loss in their following.

I've heard that many are starting to distance themselves from the Catholic Church due to their views on these topics. People are no longer aligned with their stances on these issues, which is causing them to feel uncomfortable within the church. For example, if you support abortion, you might not feel comfortable in a community where it's seen as completely wrong. Similarly, if you're for gay marriage, you might struggle in a following that doesn't agree with it.

I don't understand why the Catholic Church can't have female priests or allow priests to be married. The church claims that priests are married to God, yet everyone else in the world has both a job and a family life. I'm not sure why priests can't have both as well.

In my opinion, I’m not against gay marriage. I honestly don’t see it as a conscious choice that gay people make. It just seems like they are born that way, and we shouldn’t hold them responsible for their sexual orientation. I don’t think it’s right to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can’t. I haven’t given it much thought, but I would definitely say that’s wrong. It’s not like they have a say in how they are born. I was born straight, and someone else is born gay, it doesn’t seem fair to hold them accountable. I don’t think the federal government should be involved in this. It’s not a legal or moral issue, and I don’t think they have a right to interfere in people’s lives. It’s just who they are, and they shouldn’t be punished for that. That’s all.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized, and here’s why. There's really no solid reason to oppose it. Some people argue that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional families, but it's actually quite different. It’s like comparing two sides of the same coin. Heads will never be tails, yet it's essentially the same thing. Let’s talk about the practical aspects. Many civil rights are tied to marriage, such as property taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't be with you in a hospital or visit you because they're not technically family. That seems silly if you're spending your life with someone. Plus, scientific studies show that homosexual couples have the same relationship success rates and satisfaction rates as heterosexual couples.

The main issue is that homosexuals aren't asking for the right to marry in a church, they just want a legal document provided by the government. If there’s no religious involvement, it shouldn't be an issue. Some people, like Catholics, argue that it’s against their religion and morally wrong, but in a legal sense, if you're allowing civil unions, why not marriage? It’s like segregation: separate but unequal. Gay couples are the same in many ways, like relationship roles played by partners. People worry about adoption and community issues, but again, the main concern is how children are treated. In New York City, for instance, children of gay parents have special schools because they face bullying in public schools. But parenting skills don't differ between gay and straight couples. The federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state, and the amendment should be changed to reflect that.

President Bush has strong views on this issue, largely based on his religion, similar to his stance on abortion and stem cell research. Most of his reasons are moral, which vary from person to person. It’s unethical to embrace one group's morality while ignoring others. It’s hypocritical for the government to enforce religious standards on an entire country, considering the recent controversy over "under God” in the pledge of allegiance.

Many people are anti-gay and anti-gay marriage because they believe that gay people are psychologically damaged. But the American Psychological Association says this is untrue. If we listened to institutions that do research and studies, society might see things differently.

Let me start by sharing my experience working as a pharmacy intern over the summer. Now, it's important to note that just because a substance is illegal doesn't mean it lacks medicinal benefits. I strongly believe that while we should not make it widely available to the public just yet, utilizing it for medicinal purposes is a different story. For instance, there are controlled substances like oxycodone and Vicodin that are often used in a clinical setting because they provide genuine benefits. Denying these benefits just because of marijuana's taboo status is not productive in my opinion.

I must also emphasize that while marijuana and alcohol are both subject to abuse, marijuana is generally considered less harmful. Integrating marijuana into society gradually, rather than all at once, could be a viable solution. First, we should remove the stigma associated with marijuana to encourage responsible use. If we can achieve this, people might be better equipped to use marijuana responsibly for both recreational and medicinal purposes.

In conclusion, I contend that the benefits of marijuana should not be dismissed solely based on its illegal status. By embracing its medicinal properties and addressing the taboo surrounding it, we can pave the way for a more responsible and regulated future for marijuana.

I believe the church has made adjustments to adapt to the twenty-first century. It isn't as rigid as it used to be. When I was younger, I would always attend church every Sunday, dressed in cute little dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. I went to a private school, so I'd see all my friends there on weekends, but now, as I've aged, they've introduced a teen mass that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially during summer when you'll see folks in beach clothes, and families often arrive late. Even at morning masses, where I used to dress up, people now wear jeans and khakis. The church I know has also seen a shift in its political landscape, but I'm not privy to the intricacies. Overall, I think it has become more casual.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests and child abuse, I don't think these issues could have been prevented by allowing female priests or permitting priests to marry. Married men can still become pedophiles due to their genetics, and it's not always a lifestyle choice. Many religions allow their clergy to marry, but if a priest truly wants to practice their faith and be married, they might consider a different faith. I believe pedophilia is primarily genetic rather than environmental, and marriage wouldn't change that. If the church knew about the abuse and covered it up, it's shameful, but I believe in many cases, they may not have been aware. I have no other significant thoughts on the Catholic church.

Initially, I was fine with the initial premise, but as we were still recovering from the September 11th attacks, everyone was quite shaken. The Bush administration used various pretexts to justify going into Iraq, claiming connections to Osama Bin Laden and linking the war to the attacks. They also alleged that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which we now know were never proven true. This really grates on me, and the Iraq war has always made my blood boil.

I believe the Bush administration straightforwardly lied to the American people and has not taken responsibility for it. Even Colin Powell, who gave a major presentation at the UN, later admitted that he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time. To me, this is malfeasance in office and an impeachable offense. They have shown complete disregard for the Constitution and have been trying to undermine it ever since, especially since September 11th. I think they entered office with the intent to go to war.

I can’t recall the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who made this allegation in his book after being forced out, but it seems like the younger Bush was driven by a sense of blood vengeance against Saddam Hussein due to his father's administration. He also had long-term plans to expand our energy supply, which was quite underhanded. However, I believe the situation has dragged on long enough.

If we withdraw now, there’s a high risk of civil war and even more deaths. The alternative being considered by the UN and the US is a coalition of surrounding nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia to restore order. However, I'm not sure this is a good idea in the long term because it will bring up issues of Iraq’s sovereignty. The interim government seems to be falling apart, as the news reports suggest the Parliament isn’t very effective. The Prime Minister seems to lack control over the political process, and even Muqtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting against less than a year ago, now holds a significant number of seats in the Iraqi Parliament. The political process is quite tumultuous due to these radical elements vying for control.

None of this can be articulated in polite company.

I guess I don't really know how I feel about the War in Iraq. I mean, it's like, what's the point? It wasn't even declared a war. It's more like a big get-back-at-Iraq thing, right? I mean, who do we think did 9/11? So, I don't really follow the details of it, but I know we're kind of just over there trying to build democracy and get oil. But it's not making anyone happy, and if we stay, we'll have to try to create democracy, which takes forever. And if we leave, they'll be mad at us for messing everything up again. It's so confusing! I mean, it's like, why are we still there? I don't know! I'm not really for the war, but I don't know if I'm against it either. It's hard to say. I don't think we should call it a war anymore because it doesn't feel like one. We just have all these big guns and stuff to show we're powerful. But I don't think it's fair. It's like the Vietnam War, it was never declared, and now it's called a meaningless war. And I don't want Bush to be remembered as the worst president ever. It's just so unfair. And there are so many families with kids in Iraq, and I don't want to see them hurt. But if we stay, we'll be trying to mold them into something they're not. And that could make things worse. I mean, who knows what's going to happen in the end? It's just so hard to say. I guess it's going to go on for years.

I strongly feel it's not appropriate for a state to legalize it or for the government to even consider it. I believe it's a matter that should be left to the churches, as the constitution explicitly states the separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any regulations over it would be a breach of what's already established in the constitution. I find it hypocritical for those who are pushing for its illegality to impose their beliefs on others, particularly when most Catholics and Christians oppose it. The separation of church and state is a fundamental principle of our constitution, promoting religious tolerance. I don't see why making an amendment about this issue would be necessary or beneficial, as it would only restrict people rather than the government. I don't think the federal government should be involved in this at all. The president's push for this amendment is clearly driven by his personal beliefs as a Catholic, and it's not justified by any logical or economic reasons. In fact, it could potentially have a positive impact on society. I've said my piece on this topic.

Ok, let's talk about the war in Iraq.

Well, to get started, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for the war. Before invading Iraq, I believe there was an attempt to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality, they had very little to do with each other. The government used the emotions of the American people, who were outraged by the terrorist attacks, to justify the invasion, which started in 2003.

Now, I'm generally against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think the government should have learned from the Vietnam War. The Iraq War was, in many ways, similar to Vietnam. The U.S. removed the Iraqi government and tried to implement a democratic government, just like they did in Vietnam. But they were not prepared for the chaos and power vacuum that followed, and more importantly, they were not prepared for the insurgents who fought against them.

I think the government should have planned for all possible outcomes. The war in Iraq has been going on for years, and many American troops have died. The U.S. is still there today, trying to train Iraqi troops and police forces to police their own country. It's a long process, and I don't think the government was prepared for it.

The U.S. government also made it seem like the invasion would be a short, successful mission, which was naïve. It's not an easy thing to implement a new form of government, especially after a long war. It took our own country a long time to become the powerful democracy it is today, with a lot of tension and civil war along the way.

In the 2004 presidential election, I would have voted for George Bush to let him finish what he started, because it's hard to abandon the people we've been helping. But at the same time, we need to consider the staggering number of American casualties and how much is too much to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq.

If we're invading Iraq to make it a democratic nation, why aren't we doing the same for other countries? I think the main reason is oil. The U.S. is getting its oil from Iraq, and it's usually all about money and controlling resources. Before the invasion, there were claims that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but none were ever found. Yet, places like North Korea, which we know have these weapons, are not being attacked. I don't think the U.S. government is being thorough or truthful enough in their decisions.

I just hope it ends soon, and there's peace there soon, but probably not.

I am in favor of gay marriage, I've always been. It's a personal preference, and it's been proven to have biological roots rather than sociological ones. This means that denying people the right to marry someone they love based on something they can't control is inhumane. I've always advocated for gay marriage and I believe that politics and government should stay out of people's personal lives. In my neighborhood, there are a few openly gay couples who don't have the same rights as straight couples, but they function just like any other family. I think it's ridiculous for politicians to try and interpret marriage in a way that suits them. It's a personal matter, not a national or federal concern. I've heard from many sources that being homosexual can be influenced by biology, not upbringing. For example, a chemical reaction in the brain might predispose someone to be homosexual, rather than societal factors. It's unfair that two people can get married in secret without anyone knowing, but two gay people wanting to do the same gets front-page news. I believe marriage should be a private matter, not a public one.

I feel like the war has dragged on far too long. Initially, the purpose seemed noble: to restore democracy in a country lacking a fair political system. However, I believe we've lost sight of that goal, and now it appears we're simply continuing the conflict to assert our status as a global superpower. Perhaps there were personal interests at play, like the previous feud between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein. While spreading democracy was a valid motivation, any hint of personal gain would have been unfair. I believe our initial goal was achieved in the first few months, as the war's start itself was a significant statement. Still, the prolonged conflict has left the original purpose diluted and misconceived, as it seems we're still at war for the sake of being at war, aiming for a decisive end that may never come.

In my opinion, the war has dragged on far too long. If our main objective was to install democracy in a country ruled by a tyrant, that would have been a just cause. However, I don't think our reasons have stayed true to this original intent. It seems we're still waging war just to wage war, without a clear end goal in sight. It's high time we let the local government take the reins and step back, as they will eventually have to handle their own affairs anyway. We've been pouring billions of dollars into this conflict, which could be better spent addressing our own pressing issues like poverty and infrastructure. It's a drain on our economy to keep funding a war that has lost its purpose over time.

I wanted to clarify something. It seems that the situation you're referring to was prevented because someone went online and found some information. Anyway, I think it's okay. On platforms like Myspace, if you post information, it's pretty much accessible to everyone. You have to understand that when you give someone access to your profile, you're allowing them to see it. So, if someone spotted something and prevented a situation, that's not an invasion of privacy. However, it might be difficult to monitor every profile to ensure safety, but it becomes discriminatory if they only target the "bad kids." It depends on the context—whether they were actively searching for something specific or just stumbled upon it. I don't know, it's a tricky issue. I use Facebook, and I'm always aware that there are creepy people out there. I saw a TV show where a man easily found someone's information and convinced her to meet him. It's scary. Sometimes, people I don't recognize on my class list IM me, and I wonder if they know too much about me. It's a dangerous game balancing privacy and communication. I only accept people I know, but you never know who can see what. My roommate mentioned that her high school banned students from having Myspace, which seems a bit strange. I'm not sure if that's a privacy issue or if they had the right to do that. It's a complex situation.

I understand that they didn’t outright legalize it, but rather decriminalized it. This means that getting caught with it is treated more like getting a traffic ticket than a criminal offense. While a decriminalized charge can still have serious future ramifications, such as making it difficult to pass a job interview, it does reduce the immediate consequences of being arrested and booked. On the other hand, there are costs involved in arresting, housing, and bringing individuals to court, especially in financially struggling communities. In a place like Denver, where the community tends to be more open-minded and liberal, decriminalizing marijuana might be a good decision. This could potentially free up funds for public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. However, it's important to consider that widespread legalization could lead to marijuana being sold in gas stations and smoked in public, which might not be desirable. Additionally, while alcohol may have more immediate effects on motor skills, marijuana often has a more enduring impact on an individual's lifestyle. I don't think that either substance should be generalized, as people react differently based on their personalities and behaviors.

In my opinion, yes, there are some things that the Catholic Church has done traditionally that are quite old-fashioned. They've maintained these customs for long periods, which is good for grounding and maintaining traditions. However, it's also crucial to be open-minded to change. Many Catholics feel that they must attend Church weekly and adhere strictly to the Church's rules. This strictness sometimes makes it seem like the Church doesn't accept those who don't follow the doctrine perfectly or aren't Catholic. For instance, my parents faced difficulties when it came to getting married in the Church because my father was an Episcopalian. This isn't really tolerant of other religions, which goes against the Church's teachings on loving others. I believe many Catholic doctrines tell us what to do, but the Church's practices don't always align with these teachings due to their outdated nature. I think it's a good idea to allow priests to marry, but I don't believe it would necessarily prevent pedophilic behavior. I think priests would act that way whether they're married or not, as the act involves children, not spouses. Therefore, I don't think allowing priests to marry would deter them from these behaviors. In my view, it wouldn't make a difference.

I'm still undecided on this issue, so I can't declare one side as right or wrong. However, I believe this is one of the most complex topics we're dealing with today. The debate lies between the separation of church and state and how to define marriage, which is tricky without offending anyone. I think civil unions, regardless of the ceremony's religious context, should be treated equally by the government. After all, they're unions between two people, and the government shouldn't concern itself with the type of ceremony or religious significance. But if states can come to a logical consensus, they should push for federal recognition of civil unions. A constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is absurd; it's not a cause large enough to warrant amending the constitution. It's simply not that important to amend the constitution to define or ban gay marriage.

You know, I was brought up in a Christian household, so my views on homosexuality are a bit nuanced. I've got a lot of gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather a decision left to each state. I mean, there are so many democratic and republican states, and you can't deny that democratic states will likely push for gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you're choosing to live there, so you should accept that state's position on the issue. I believe homosexuals deserve the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I think the decision should be up to each state.

I also think Bush shouldn't have a say in whether or not the whole country should be against gay marriage. I mean, he doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't dictate how each state wants to run. Plus, he'll be out of office soon enough, so it doesn't matter what he decides. I think some things are better left up to the individual states, as they'll be the ones to live with the decision. Let's just leave it at that.

So, no, I don't think they should do that at all. Let me explain why. Myspace, it's a public platform, right? If you look at the definition, it's basically for people to see whatever you post. Now, if you post something on the internet, you have to realize that people will see it. It could be school officials or anyone else. They might see something you didn't intend for them to see. But, if something on the internet could potentially prevent a school shooting, then I think that's perfectly fine. It's the school officials' responsibility to ensure the safety of students, and this might help them do just that. Now, if they're just using the internet to catch students in trouble, that's an invasion of privacy. But if they're doing it for the greater good, to make the school safer, then I don't think it's an invasion at all. I mean, if you're a student posting something on Myspace and you don't expect to get in trouble, that's crazy. Everything you post on the internet is for the world to see, and it can come back to bite you later. If you don't want something to be seen, don't post it. And if they have something that leads them to make the school a safer place, then it's fine. But if they're just doing it to catch students, that's not good. It's like they're dropping their kids off at school and expecting it to be a safe place, and the school officials are doing their duty to ensure that. That's why they do drills and practice for emergencies. They're just trying to make the school safer and prevent anything bad from happening, like what happened at Columbine. That's all I have to say.
